'''''Daedalea quercina''''' is a species of mushroom in the order [[Polyporales]], and the [[type species]] of the genus ''[[Daedalea]]''. Commonly known as the '''oak mazegill''' or '''maze-gill fungus''', the [[botanical name|specific epithet]] refers to the oak genus ''[[Quercus]]'', upon which it frequently grows, causing a [[Wood-decay fungus#Brown rot|brown rot]]. It is found in Europe, Asia, Northern Africa and Australasia.  Though inedible, it can be used as a natural comb and has been the subject of chemical research.

==Description==
[[File:Daedalea quercina - Eichen-Wirrling - oak mazegill - maze-gill fungus - dédalée du chêne - 03.jpg|thumb|left|''Daedalea quercina'' fruitbodies on ecorticated stump]]
The [[Sessility (botany)|sessile]], fan-shaped fruiting bodies are typically {{convert|3|–|20|cm|in}} in diameter and up to {{convert|8|cm|in}} thick. They are found singly or in tiered groups, usually on rotting oak. The upper surface of the cap may be various shades of brown, and is sometimes [[wikt:zonate|zonate]]. The pore surface, white to tan in color, is initially porous, but as the fruit body matures, some of the pore walls break down, forming slits with blunt partitions. This results in the characteristic maze-like (daedaloid or labyrinthinine/labyrinthiform) appearance. The tube walls are 10–30 mm long, with thick walls. The [[basidiospore]]s are 5–7 × 2–4 [[micrometre|µm]], smooth, and elliptical in shape. In [[spore print|deposit]] the spores are white.

This mushroom is inedible due to its cork-like texture.

A variant has been described that has large, angular pores similar to those in the genus ''[[Trametes]]'', named ''D. quercina'' forma ''trametea''.<ref>Schanzle RW. (1973). "''Daedalea quercina'' forma ''trametea'' in Illinois." ''[[Mycologia]]'' '''65'''(3): 689–690.</ref>

==Habitat and distribution==

Although ''D. quercina'' prefers to grow on ''[[Quercus]]'' species, it has also been found on the tree species ''[[Fagus grandifolia]]'', ''[[Fraxinus americana]]'', ''[[Juglans nigra]]'', and ''[[Ulmus americana]]''.<ref>Overholts LO. (1939). "Geographical distribution of some American polyporaceae." ''[[Mycologia]]'' '''13'''(6): 629–652.</ref>

It has been reported from nearly all European countries, following the pattern of oak distribution. It has also been reported in [[Northern Africa]] ([[Tunisia]]), [[Asia]] from [[Caucasus]] to [[India]], and also [[Australia]].<ref>Kotlaba F. (1984). Zeměpisné rozšiřeni a ekologie chorošů (Polyporales s. l.) v Československu
[The range and ecology of Polyporales species in Czechoslovakia Republik]. ''Věd. Česk.Akad. Praha.''</ref>

==Uses==

Fruit bodies of ''D. quercina'' have been used as a natural comb, employed for brushing down horses with tender skin.<ref name="isbn0-486-23105-4">{{cite book |author=Rolfe F. |title=The Romance of the Fungus World: an Account of Fungus Life in its Numerous Guises, both Real and Legendary |publisher=Dover Publications |location=New York |year=1974 |pages= |isbn=0-486-23105-4 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} p. 158.</ref> Gilbertson notes that in England, smoldering fruit bodies were used for anesthetizing bees.<ref>Gilbertson RL. (1980). "Wood-rotting fungi of North America."''[[Mycologia]]'' '''72'''(1): 1–49.</ref>

This species has been investigated for application in [[bioremediation]].<ref name="pmid18373237">{{cite journal |author=Asgher M |author2=Bhatti HN |author3=Ashraf M |author4=Legge RL |title=Recent developments in biodegradation of industrial pollutants by white rot fungi and their enzyme system |journal=Biodegradation |volume=19 |issue=6 |pages=771–83 |date=November 2008 |pmid=18373237 |doi=10.1007/s10532-008-9185-3 |url=}}</ref> The [[lignin]]-degrading [[enzyme]] [[laccase]], isolated and purified from ''D. quercina'', has shown use in biodegrading a variety of toxic [[dye]]s and [[pigment]]s.<ref name="pmid14504838">{{cite journal |author=Baldrian P. |title=Purification and characterization of laccase from the white-rot fungus ''Daedalea quercina'' and decolorization of synthetic dyes by the enzyme |journal=Appl. Microbiol. Biotechnol. |volume=63 |issue=5 |pages=560–3 |date=February 2004 |pmid=14504838 |doi=10.1007/s00253-003-1434-0 |url=}}</ref>

The compound [[quercinol]] (a [[chromene]] derivative), isolated from the oak mazegill, has [[anti-inflammatory]] activity, and inhibits the enzymes [[COX-2|cyclooxygenase 2]], [[xanthine oxidase]], and [[horseradish peroxidase]].<ref name="pmid17346963">{{cite journal |author=Gebhardt P |author2=Dornberger K |author3=Gollmick FA |author4= Gräfe U |author5=Härtl A |author6= Görls H |author7=Schlegel B |author8=Hertweck C. |title=Quercinol, an anti-inflammatory chromene from the wood-rotting fungus ''Daedalea quercina'' (Oak Mazegill) |journal=Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. |volume=17 |issue=9 |pages=2558–60 |date=May 2007 |pmid=17346963 |doi=10.1016/j.bmcl.2007.02.008 |url=}}</ref>
